body_content.explanation: small in length, distance, or height:
examples: a short skirt
Her hair is much shorter than it used to be.
It's only a short walk to the station.
I'm fairly short but my brother's very tall.

body_content.explanation: used to say that a name is used as a shorter form of another name:
examples: Her name's Jo - it's short for Josephine.
Her name's Josephine, or Jo for short.

body_content.explanation: being an amount of time that is less than average or usual:
examples: a short film/visit
He's grown so much in such a short time.
I work much better if I take a short break every hour or so.

body_content.explanation: Short books, letters, and other examples of writing do not contain many words and do not take much time to read:
examples: It's a very short book - you'll read it in an hour.

body_content.explanation: to not have enough of something:
examples: to be short of space/time
We're short on coffee - I'd better get some more.
The bill comes to £85, but we're £15 short.
I'm a little short (= I do not have much money) this week - could you lend me ten dollars?

body_content.explanation: unable to breathe very well, for example because you have been running or doing some type of energetic exercise:
examples: She's always short of breath when she climbs the stairs.

body_content.explanation: to be few or not enough in number:
examples: Free desks are in short supply in this office.

body_content.explanation: to not have something, especially when it is something you need in order to live:
examples: My parents didn't have much money, but they made sure we didn't go short (of anything).

body_content.explanation: saying little but showing slight impatience or anger in the few words that you say:
examples: I'm sorry if I was a bit short with you on the phone this morning.

body_content.explanation: a drink of spirits (= type of strong alcohol) without water or any other liquid added:
examples: She only drinks shorts, never wine or beer.

body_content.explanation: a short film, especially one made for showing before the main film at a cinema

in baseball, the position on the inner part of the field between second base (= one of the positions on a square that a player must reach in order to score) and third base, or the player at that position:
examples: a ground ball to short
Tommy will play short and bat third for us.

body_content.explanation:
informal for
short-circuit : to have or cause a bad electrical connection that makes the current flow in the wrong direction, which often has the effect of stopping the power supply:
examples: Circuit breakers shorted, which cut off power to safety systems throughout the plant.
The plumber shorted the washing machine.

body_content.explanation: to treat someone unfairly, by giving them less than they deserve, or less than what is needed or usual:
examples: She calculated that many of the state's 176 school districts were being shorted a total of $161 million annually.
He said the company has shorted him $500 in the past six months.

body_content.explanation: to sell a share or currency that you have borrowed when you think its price is going to fall, with the intention of buying it back later at a lower price, then keeping the profit after paying back what you borrowed:
examples: At the time it was the market's most shorted stock - with traders staking more than £100 million on the share price falling.
One famous example was when George Soros shorted the pound in 1992, and Britain was forced out of the European exchange rate mechanism.

body_content.explanation: before the arranged or expected time or place:
examples: We wanted to explain the plans fully, but the chairman stopped us short, as there were other important matters to discuss.

body_content.explanation: used with adjectives ending in -ed formed from nouns to describe something with a short part:
examples: a short-haired dog (= a dog with short hair)
a short-sleeved shirt (= a shirt with short sleeves)
